qas.question: Why did the FCC reject systems such as MUSE?
What was increasing and consuming a lot of bandwidth?
Who rejected systems such as MUSE as the new standard for the US?
What was one of the requirements for a new standard system in the US?

answers.text: had to be more efficient, needing less bandwidth

qas.question: What was the existing system at the time?
Why did the ECC reject systems such as MUSE?
What was decreasing and consuming a lot of bandwidth?
Who rejected systems such as MUSE as the old standard for the US?
What was one of the requirements for an old standard system in the US?
What wasn't the existing system at the time?

context: Several systems were proposed as the new standard for the US, including the Japanese MUSE system, but all were rejected by <a2_0>the <b7_0>FCC<b7_0/><a2_0/> because of <a0_0>their <b5_0>higher bandwidth requirements<b5_0/><a0_0/>. At this time, the number of <a1_0><b6_0>television channels<b6_0/><a1_0/> was growing rapidly and bandwidth was already a problem. A new standard <a3_0><b8_0>had to be more efficient<b8_0/>, needing less bandwidth<a3_0/> for HDTV than the existing <a4_0><b9_0>NTSC<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
